ul: Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5 Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

Provides interoperability with non-wcf clients that support the ws* stack. Supports the WS* stack including reliable messaging, message security, and secure transactions. Message security is turned on by default, transport security is also available. Allows the service to be hosted in IIS 5 or IIS 6. If you choose transport security you can use certificates, Windows, or token authentication. If you choose message security you can use certificates, Username, Windows, or Issue token authentication (Windows CardSpace).

For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspxFor binding Q&A, see the Binding section of “WCF 3.5 Questions and Answers “ at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=WCF%20Questions%20and%20Answers%20%28Q%26A%29&referringTitle=Home

Message security is turned on by default, transport security is also available.
Allows the service to be hosted in IIS 5 or IIS 6.
If you choose transport security you can use certificates, Windows, or token authentication.
If you choose message security you can use certificates, Username, Windows, or Issue token authentication (Windows CardSpace).
For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspx

pre: <system.serviceModel>....    <services>        <service behaviorConfiguration="" name="WCFServicecHost.MyService">            ...            <endpoint address="" binding="wsHttpBinding" bindingConfiguration=""                name="wsBinding" contract="WCFServicecHost.IMyService" />            ...        </service>    </services></system.serviceModel>

html:
Applies to

  • Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5
  • Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

What to Do

If your service will be called by clients over the Internet, consider using the wsHttpBinding.

Why

The wsHttpBinding has the following characteristics:

  • Provides interoperability with non-wcf clients that support the ws* stack.
  • Supports the WS* stack including reliable messaging, message security, and secure transactions.
  • Message security is turned on by default, transport security is also available.
  • Allows the service to be hosted in IIS 5 or IIS 6.
  • If you choose transport security you can use certificates, Windows, or token authentication.
  • If you choose message security you can use certificates, Username, Windows, or Issue token authentication (Windows CardSpace).

When

wsHttpBinding is a good choice for Internet scenarios in which you do not have to support legacy clients which expect an ASMX web service. If you do need to support legacy clients, consider using basicHttpBinding instead.

How

The following example shows how to configure wsHttpBinding:

<system.serviceModel>
....
    <services>
        <service behaviorConfiguration="" name="WCFServicecHost.MyService">
            ...
            <endpoint address="" binding="wsHttpBinding" bindingConfiguration=""
                name="wsBinding" contract="WCFServicecHost.IMyService" />
            ...
        </service>
    </services>
</system.serviceModel>

Additional Resources

  • For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspx
  • For binding Q&A, see the Binding section of “WCF 3.5 Questions and Answers “ at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=WCF%20Questions%20and%20Answers%20%28Q%26A%29&referringTitle=Home

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
